At {{c1::low (1-3mcg/kg/min)}} dose infusion, adrenaline has {{c2::beta-2}} effects, such as {{c3::vasodilation and bronchodilation}} (two).
Adrenaline is a {{c1::positive}} inotrope and {{c1::positive}} chronotrope, and therefore causes {{c2::increased}} cardiac output and {{c3::increased}} myocardial oxygen consumption.
At {{c1::moderate (~3mcg/kg/min)}} infusion, adrenaline causes {{c2::beta-1}} agonism, and thus causes {{c3::increased}} inotropy and chronotropy
At {{c1::high dose (>3mcg/kg/min)}} infusions, adrenaline primarily has {{c2::alpha}} effects and acts as a {{c3::vasoconstrictor}}

{{c1::Adrenaline}} cannot be given orally, because it is rapidly metabolised by {{c2::catechol-o-methyl transferase}} in {{c3::the GI tract}} and {{c4::monoamine oxidase}} in {{c5::the GI tract and liver}}.
Glass vials, to be mixed with 5% dextrose or saline solution

Alpha: increased SVR, increased DBP, therefore increased DBP; increased venoconstriction, increased venous return therefore increased preload
Beta: Inotropy and chronotropy; may have compensatory bradycardia
Increased afterload and beta effects may increase myocardial work and oxygen consumption

Vasopressin and its analogues act via G-protein vasopressin receptors V1, V2, and V3, and has affinity for oxytocin-type receptors

CVS: increased MAP and SVR; pulmonary arterial vasodilation in hypoxia and physiological conditions
GU: reduced urine output and polydipsia in central DI
Haematological: increase vWF and factor VII
Desmopressin is only analogue that can be given PO, SL or IN
Variable per analogue; generally low Vd
65% argipressin and desmopressin excreted unchanged in urine
The three synthetic analogues of vasopressin are {{c1::argipressin, terlipressin and desmopressin}}
Endogenous vasopressin and its synthetic analogues act via {{c1::G-protein vasopressin receptors V1, V2, and V3}}, and also has affinity for {{c2::oxytocin-like receptors}}.

Vasopressin:
V1 receptors are present in {{c1::vascular smooth muscle, platelets, and myometrium}}. Activation leads to {{c2::increased intracellular calcium concentrations and vasoconstriction}}

Vasopressin:
V2 receptors are found in the {{c1::distal renal tubule and collecting ducts}}, and activation leads to aquaporin-2 trafficking from intracellular vesicle membranes within renal epithelial cells into the apical cell membrane, allowing {{c2::water reabsorption}}. 
V2 receptors are also present on {{c1::endothelial cells}}, allowing {{c2::von Willebrand factor (vWF)}} release that prevents the breakdown of factor VIII in plasma.

Vasopressin:
V3 receptors are found in the {{c1::pituitary}} and contribute to {{c2::ACTH release}}.

Vasopressin:
Oxytocin-type receptors are present on {{c1::vascular smooth muscle and the myometrium}}, and activation results in {{c2::increased NO synthase activity leading to vasodilation}}.
{{c1::Desmopressin}} has {{c2::ten times the anti-diuretic}} action of {{c1::endogenous vasopressin}}, but {{c2::1500 times less vasoconstriction effect}}

fields:
III Vaughan-Williams antiarrhythmic 
Benzofuran derivative, structurally resembling thyroxine

Historically classed as K+ channel blocker, but also affects Na+, Ca++, and adrenoceptors (all four classes)
Prolongs AP and delays refractory period
Partial alpha and beta antagonism by reducing receptor number or inhibiting GPCR system from activating adenylyl cyclase
CVS: depresses AVN automaticity and conduction; increases AP duration; prolongs QTc

CVS: hypotension, AV block
Resp: pneumonitis
CNS: CNS toxicity
Hepatic: cirrhosis
Metabolic: hypo OR hyperthyroidism; peripheral neuropathy
Occular: corneal microdeposits (reversible)
Cardiac glycoside derived from dry leaves of digitalis (the foxglove)

Direct: Na+/K+/ATPase inhibition --> increases intracellular Na+, decreases K+ causing reduced Na+-Ca++ pump action --> increased intracellular Ca++ --> inotropy
Indirect: modifies autonomic activity and increases efferent vagal activity
CVS: inotropy, automaticity and contractility; slows HR (decreased SAN, slows AVN, increase AVN refractory period

CVS: arrhythmia, esp junctional bradycardia, ventricular bigeminy, 2* or 3* HB
GI: anorexia, n/v/d, abdo pain
CNS: headache, drowsiness, confusion, visual change, coma

50-70% excreted unchanged; dependent on renal function
T1/2 36-48h
What are the ECG changes associated with digoxin?

Prolonged PR
ST depression
T wave flattening
QT shortening
